The dock leads into a small plaza formed by the non-palacial
palace on
the right, Goverment building and Post Of ice opposite the
and real
estate (subjeet to improvement) on the left.
plaza and the
pier were teening with people--9% black--when we came
The few whites had all the places of vantage and even the
bronzed Portuguese looked anow-white in comparison with the stove-
polish black of the natives.
Many of the latter wore only gee-strings.
One of those had approsched our Chief Mechanie a few weeks ago and in
perfoet Oxfordian English had offered to assist in any way that he
could--finally indicating that we need only ask for "Thunderbolt MeCoy".
However,
he was not around when we landed.
I
suppose Mr. WIllklo welcomed the firat complete exeuption
from reporters that he has had in many, many months!
At least he
sooned to enjoy thoroughly every ninute of his stay in Bolane.
The
Portuguese officials wore, of course, profoundly impressed and hardly
knew what to do.
The coning of the Clipper was enough of an event to
stun them,
but when Mr. Willkie and Mr. Trippe were added it was just
too much.
The
guard of honor--a Portuguese Major and ten jet black
natives in faded khaki uniforms, red fes hats, and baze beaver-tail-
shaped feet-stood at attention while we trooped into the Palace grounds
for a photograph.
Later an autonobile trip around tom and to a nearby
native village.
We met the obief in a once-white mit, and twelve of
his trenty-six wives in no suits at all (the rest were working in the
peanut fields).
Later still, a reception and tea at the Palace and then-
what with the first flight covers to be cancelled and other jobs ineident
to a first
flight--nothing ever runa snoothly--it vas too dark to take
off and so we decided to stay another day.
Back we went fron the Dixie
Clipper to the Company's staff house.
They got together a diner for us which was very
good-if fru-
gal.
I sat at a mall table with lira. Long, wife of our Bolane airport
manager,
Willkie, and Mr. Trippo.
Naturally, I never expeeted to
dine in darkest Africa with or without Mr. Willkie, nor least of all,
I suspoot,
did Mra. Long.
She was the daughter of a Scotchman who spent
many yesre
at Horts.
There she net and married Long, and they seened
to be an ideal
couple to send to Bolena for both speak Portuguese.
We had enough beds for all at the ataff house.
we boarded & small steambost as the guests of the Governor,
mainland and
miles.
Wish you could have seen me sitting in that truck on a box with
a sun helmet on my head and an Army rifle over my nees while me rattled
over a winding red clay road through the jungle.
was with me
and in the sane truck two Portuguese officers, neither of
whon could speak English but both of whom could speak French about as
well me I
It was something of a strain linguistically and physically.
My rifle,
which weighed about 20 lba., was a "three man gun"-one nan
holds the rifle and two men hold him.
Fortunately we only saw many
monkeys and one small gasolle which was out of range.
I say "fortunately"
for I wouldn't have shot that gun for all the tes in China,
